so the mixture out what mixed rally what is what is mixed reality a lot of you already know you've tried it you know
what it is but for those who haven't tried a mixture of the device mixed reality is this spectrum between the
real world and the digital world and on one end you've got virtuality where you cut off from the real world you're in a
imaginary world with no stuck rules and then you've got augmentuality where you're having to
deal with the real world but you're adding in or mixing in digital elements and the hololens too is on that side of
the spectrum this is the hololens 2. it's a wearable computer it doesn't attach to anything
it's contains all its own storage and compute and it doesn't have a traditional
display it has a transparent display so you can still walk around see the world talk to people look people in the eye
but you're seeing digital objects or holograms embedded in the real world
and it's got a lot of sensors it's got eight cameras two eye tracking cameras four cameras that are looking around in the
environment tracking how you're moving and it's got five microphones and it's using all these sensors to
to orientate yourself and to try and interpret what you want to do and it uses all that
that uh those sensors let's do this to embed holographic objects in the real world
particularly for work so it's not a it's not an entertainment device and you can also look at holograms
together using multiple devices and this is a big part of what microsoft mesh is
trying to enable is these sorts of collaborative scenarios and this is how you interact with the
hololens too you're using your hands so you can press holographic buttons and you can reach out and grab holographic objects and move them around
but what's the the point of that what does that give you that computing on a traditional screen doesn't give you
uh one thing that you can do using mixed reality devices like the whole lens too is you can embed data in the real world
um so in this case this is i'm going to go through a couple of projects example projects from surprise terrier this is a
project where we took the 3d plans for a building and embedded them on the construction site so you're
able to be on the construction site in the real world and look at what is planned to be built you're able to say
this is what we're planning to build and this is what we've actually done so far and do they line up have we have we made
any changes already have we deviated from the plan and you're able to see things within the walls and within the
floors and so that's a way to empower the people that are working in the real world and don't traditionally have
access to this sort of information in this way so it's a way to give people out in the field
digital superpowers so that's one way mixture id can be useful to take data into the real world and place it in a
way that is meaningful and useful for people another thing that makes reality is useful for is for looking at things that
are innately 3d so there's a lot of objects in the world that are 3d 3d machinery 3d places
and 3d anatomy so people are are three-dimensional creatures but when
surgeons are planning for a surgery they're looking at a 2d screen most of the time they're looking at 2d
medical imagery a number of slices on a 2d screen and they're using their imagination to
turn that into a 3d image in their head each surgeon is looking at the same 2d image and saying well this is what i
think it is actually going to look like in 3d but they don't know until they open up the patient if they're correct
and they can't really compare their mental 3d models with each other or have a meaningful
communication in 3d so for this project for the holocare project we're taking the patients to the medical

time this is a hologram of a patient's liver with a tumor that needs to be removed and they're able to have uh

same for heart surgery aimed the same experience of of what this 3d object looks like what the structure of the
organ looks like and have a conversation about how to approach the problem
and of course we've also enabled it so that specialists from other cities and hospitals can be present in those
planning sessions as avatars and so you have
people represented as these avatars and they're using the hand tracking or homelands too to allow them to to emote
and point to things and you can hear their voice coming spatially from that that avatar and you're able to
yeah have a conversation in the same in the same room together uh remotely to to
discuss the structures of the heart or the liver
and finally this is a more experimental project around holoportation and this is where you're
capturing a person in 3d we're using a depth camera called the zero connect and then we're displaying that
3d capture uh in real time on a whole lens too so it's a it's a volumetric
video uh communication so it's a it's like a live star wars style hologram of a person
and the purpose of this sort of project is to get closer to uh real life communication closer than
you can get via video conversations so when you're
in the room it's it's hard to see on video but when you're in this room uh with a holograph uh live hologram of
person it triggers all the social cues so you want to give them personal space and you want to look them in the eye you
want them to look in the eye so you're reacting to this hologram not as a video but as if it
were a person in the room
and now i'm going to talk about one of the challenges of mixed reality and this is this is very relevant because this is
one of the core things that microsoft mesh is trying to solve and this is the the problem of okay if we're placing
digital oligo uh objects holograms in the real world how do we locate them how do we specify
there should be a hologram there and it should be there for me and it should be there for you
so this is a 17th century map of scandinavia and
yeah it doesn't look like such a safe place particularly off the coast of of norway there's a lot of sea monsters
there and this is an example of um of the phrase here be dragons that
that people used to draw maps with monsters in uncharted and potentially dangerous areas
and you know nowadays we like to think okay we're maybe gone past that point because we've
got google maps and we've got gps but gps is only accurate in terms of meters and it doesn't work
effectively inside buildings so we've still got monsters in the buildings effectively those are still
unmapped and potentially dangerous areas and this is a problem
in terms of of placing holograms so how do we how do we place holograms in the world and
like boats if you don't anchor a boat you can't expect it to be there the next day it'll float away it's the same with
holograms if you don't anchor a hologram to a particular point that's immovable
in the real world you can't expect it to be there the next day to persist
so there's different ways of anchoring holograms you can anchor it to a fiducial marker an image that the whole
lens 2 can recognize consistently and accurately so you can use a qr code or there's a number of other
computer vision solvable image recognitions systems that you can use and then if you
recognize that image you can place holograms relative to it and that's yeah it's very reliable it's very
accurate but it means you have to mark up the world with all these uh images which isn't always ideal
another thing you can use as anchoring is the the spatial mesh that the whole lens 2 generates of the world around it
so it's tracking you as you're moving around so in a real time 3d mapping of this space that you're in so in this example it's
mapping the bench and the chairs as i'm walking around and in the end you get a 3d mesh something like this
and you can use this uh to do some anchoring you can anchor holograms to this mesh you could say okay there's a
chair there i want to put a holographic person in that chair and then if you're in the same space and
you recognize you look at this mesh and you say oh yeah i'm also in this space you can also have a holographic person
in that chair so that's another way to to anchor holograms because ideally what you want is you
want to have a removable point specified somewhere in the real world okay that's 2 meters from this wall
three meters from that wall you want that anchor to not move and then you want to place digital content relative
to that anchor so that you can put digital content in meaningful and useful and replicable places in the
world if you can do that you can come into a space recognize some sort of unique
fingerprint and place a hologram say a holographic gem on one device and then another user comes back at another time
they recognize that fingerprint and they're able to recall the position of that hologram in the same place
and then you can also do that simultaneously if you all have a shared anchor you can say okay we will all see
this holographic gem in this location and be able to collaborate around that digital object so this is part of the
the microsoft uh part of the problem that microsoft mesh is trying to solve and if that can be solved and you can
take the monsters off the map you can start filling the world with useful things like 3d
models of buildings and live sensor data you can start to do really interesting collaborative experiences so you can
clarificate across time you can leave digital objects in the world for others
like if you're doing maintenance on a real world piece of equipment you can tag information onto that rule location
you can have collaboration in the same space so you can design together or surgeons can can decide to
discuss a surgical problem together or do design together on new products you
can also collaborate across space so maybe i'm in a factory working on particular problem
and then i have a remote expert that is helping me solve a problem and adding holograms into my world
there's all sorts of opportunities for collaboration that open up once you have that anchoring problem solved

so microsoft mesh the the development platform um the development platform has to exist because whenever you're trying
to build mixed reality collaborate experiences you're usually bumping up against some of the same problems no
matter what domain you're working in there's a few common problems that you have to solve in order to get them to work
one of them is that you if you want to load 3d models into your application uh it can be
non-trivial there's a lot of different formats depending on the industry okay it's coming from the building industry or it's coming from the health industry
you have to maybe do some conversion you have to think about performance okay is this 3d model actually going to render on the
device that i have so dealing with all the different levels of detail and all the different file formats uh for 3d models can be is
something you have to deal with another problem is that uh yeah it's hard to represent people in 3d um you
know whether you're using avatars or another system it's not a trivial problem in terms of development effort
in order to solve that and another is the anchoring problem how do you anchor things so that people are
seeing things at the same time at the same place
and the last one is how do you synchronize all the actions of all the users so basically networking um so there's a lot of
networking solutions out there but they're not always optimized for for mixed reality and it's not
necessarily something that's like trivial to to implement
so this is the point of microsoft mesh for developers is that it's designing to to cut down the complexity of of mixture
of the development and solve some of these common problems that you always have to to solve no matter what application you're building

so there's three services spatial anchors remote rendering and object anchors i'm going to talk about
spatial anchors first um and these are yeah these are very important this is
very important to the anchoring problem for mixed reality so spatial anchor um like we talked
about it's a it's a point an unmovable point in in the real world uh two meters
from that wall one meter from that wall and the idea is that you can once you have that point you can attach holograms
to it um but that that anchor is not itself a 3d model it's just a place in the room
that you can attach 3d models to and the point of azure special anchors is to have a very lightweight very small
bandwidth anchor that you can pass around to different users so you can very quickly create an anchor and then
say okay you guys can have the anchor as well and then we can very quickly say collaborate and see the same holograms
in the same place and this is what it looks like behind the scenes um this this series of dots
so what the service does um whether you're on the whole lens to another device it looks around at the
space that you're in and it picks out feature points so these could be the gaps between physical objects or it
could be a an area of high contrast and it's using that to make a sparse
point cloud of the area so this is like a 3d fingerprint of the space so it doesn't send any photos or videos of
your location to the cloud but it sends this point this sparse point cloud and then
you don't really get it back but you can check against it so it's like a 3d fingerprint that you can check against and say hey am i here am i matching
against this fingerprint and if so you know you can get an anchor and you can attach holographic content to it
but uh the location matters of course because you're generating a 3d fingerprint of the area the area matters
you know it's using things like features from the furniture and uh images from or textures from the wall so
if you if you use it try and create a zero special anchor in an empty room
with nothing on the walls and nothing on the floor it's not going to work very well because it's not going to be a very unique fingerprint
and these are special anchor services is very well uh it's the most well supported across platforms of the mix
charlie services so it works across whole lens one and two but also across ios and android so that means you can
create an anchor on a on an iphone and then load it on hololens too
and that's one of the the use cases that you can use it for collaboration so you can have one user using say a tablet
they're creating an anchor placing a object relevant to that anchor uploading that to cloud and then another user is
downloading another device and then they can very quickly see the same content in the same place and they can collaborate
together in real time another use case is just persistence
over time so one user places a holographic car on a table using one device that information is sent up to
the cloud and then another user comes back another day using another device like the whole lens two and sees the same content there
so it's as if the 3d object lives in that space and then also wayfinding because spatial
anchors can have spatial relationships you can say this anchor is five meters in this direction from this
other anchor so you can use it for wayfinding if you find one anchor you can direct users to to find other points
of interest in the space so you can use it for indoor gps like navigation
and that's relevant to a lot of industries so it's relevant to manufacturing because you can add say iot information
in the right location you can leave taskless or relevant information attached to
machinery it's useful for retail because you can use indoor navigation to guide people

and it's useful for architecture and construction because you can do design reviews together in 3d and you can also

so that's available now and it's available across a lot of azure
regions supported across um yeah a lot of a lot of platforms but you're
connectivity dependent so you need connectivity both for saving and loading of azure anchors
and then another service for for anchoring the world world is azure
object anchors and while spatial anchors is about anchoring in a place a particular place
object anchors is about anchoring to a particular object and it's only supported on the whole lens too
how this works is that you have a 3d model of an object say a car or a
large boiler and you upload that 3d model into the cloud and does some processing and it generates an object
model that you download to your device and then you can match against that device in high precision
on the whole lens too so it's a great way to do very high high precision locking of holographic
content against real world objects but there's a size restriction so the objects have to be more than a meter and
less than 10 meters in every dimension and they have to be rigid they have to be rigid objects for you to be able to
match against them uh so a car is a great example uh so
toyota uses this technology for their service technicians so they have a 3d model of this uh of this car it's their
car they've uploaded it to the cloud generated a object model they can match against the home lens too and then once
they've matched they can see the internals of the car or the service technicians can see the internals of the car to help them do their job so they
can see different parts highlighted as they're doing their work and this is a great use case for
object anchors for for adding holographic training instructions or holographic
guide instructions or helpers or for logging information against the real
world object to say okay i did some maintenance against this object i want that record maybe you record a video if
you're doing the maintenance let's attach that to the real world object
but because you're depending on a rigid model to detect against if you open to
the car doors it maybe wouldn't match so if you wanted to have a
car with doors open uh detection you'd have to create another model and upload that and say okay let's look for
for both these models at the same time and that's that's available uh in it's
in public preview now so it's a free service um so it's not available in many regions
but it is free for people to test out and that is um that's dependent on
connectivity for the uploading of the model but then once you have the model you can use it offline

uh without uh without dropping performance about say this other model here so

to have this ability to anchor 3d objects in the real world you know if if this water bottle is uh a hologram and

platform it's designed to be invisible to users to be the the platform and the
development kit behind different applications but it's designed to allow
allow you to do amazing things to to move beyond uh simple video calls and to start having

in-person experiences digitally so going back to these two
projects super stereo projects you know we spend a lot of time the mixed reality developers at southwest
area uh solving you know some solving some of these important uh mixed rally problems how do
you anchor things in the real world reliably and accurately and how do you enable collaboration uh between
people both locally and remotely uh you know these are these are fun challenging
problems but it takes a lot of time and you have to solve these problems no matter what domain it is whether it's
the construction site or the medical field and so the promise of microsoft mesh for us is that okay
we don't have to worry about these repeatable problems that have to be sold in order to now allow uh mixed rather
collaboration we can just turn those turn those features on in a way and then focus on okay what's
the value for these specific domains what's what's the value for the construction side or what's the value for the surgeons and focus our
development time on those problems rather than general mixed reality problems so that's really promising for
us and it's really promising for us for for user testing as well because even if
our application doesn't doesn't need collaboration for whatever reason one of the ways that we test these applications
is by for for the holocaust for example when we're talking to surgeons and talking about new features and testing them out
we'll often have conversations with them from within the application so they'll be using the application working on
testing out a feature looking at a particular organ and we'll be in there as well either locally or remotely as
avatars and going through the application with them seeing what they're seeing and have a conversation within the application and that's a
great way to to test and something you need to do for mixed reality applications is is
always test with the people that are using the applications and always test with them um in their environments that
they work because you're not working from a screen you're working on the construction side or maybe the operating
theater and so it's so important to have a very tight feedback loop with the users and so
we think microsoft mesh is going to make that process of testing you know when you develop an application you don't
